author: @le_parisien
title: Conflit Isra√´l - Hezbollah : que peut faire la France ?
text:
Conflit Isra√´l - Hezbollah : que peut faire la France ?
La diplomatie fran√ßaise s‚Äôactive pour stopper l‚Äôembrasement au Liban. Si Paris ne p√®se gu√®re dans la r√©gion, il dispose n√©anmoins de certains atouts. D√©cryptage.
Dans son discours √† la tribune des Nations Unies, mercredi √† New York (√âtats-Unis), Emmanuel Macron l‚Äôa martel√© : ¬´ Il ne doit pas et il ne peut pas y avoir de guerre au Liban. ¬ª Mais il n‚Äôa pas √©voqu√©, √† ce moment-l√†, l‚Äôinitiative d‚Äôune ¬´ plate-forme de cessez-le-feu de vingt et un jours ¬ª entre Isra√´l et le Hezbollah. Tout simplement parce que les diplomates, fran√ßais et am√©ricains notamment, en √©taient encore au stade de la finalisation, des ultimes n√©gociations sur son contenu.
D√®s son discours achev√©, le chef de l‚Äô√âtat s‚Äôest rendu √† l‚Äôh√¥tel Intercontinental, o√π s√©journe Joe Biden, √† deux pas du si√®ge onusien. La crise libanaise occupe une bonne part de la rencontre. D‚Äôautant qu‚Äôau m√™me moment, une r√©union sp√©ciale du Conseil de s√©curit√© de l‚ÄôONU d√©marre sur ce th√®me, √† la demande de la France, et en pr√©sence du nouveau ministre des Affaires √©trang√®res, Jean-No√´l Barrot. Macron, lui, quitte New York pour une visite officielle au Canada.
Se connecter

author: time news
title: The imam who called the flag ‚Äúsatanic‚Äù is arrested and expelled from France - TIme News
text: Imam Mahjoub Mahjoubi, who described the French flag as ‚Äúsatanic‚Äù during a sermon at the mosque, was arrested this Wednesday at his home in Bagnols-sur-C√®ze, in the south of the country, and transferred to an administrative detention center in the Paris region to, finally, be expelled from France. According to the order of the Ministry of the Interior, to which the newspaper Le Figaro had access, Mahjoubi is accused of ‚Äútransmitting a literal, retrograde, intolerant and violent conception of Islam in a way that encourages behavior contrary to the values of the Republic, to discrimination against women, identity withdrawal, tensions with the Jewish community and jihadist radicalization.‚Äù In parallel, the Muslim cleric is investigated by the N√Æmes Prosecutor‚Äôs Office for alleged advocacy of terrorism. Mahjoubi‚Äôs lawyer, Samir Hamroun, said his client and his family were in shock at the arrest and the manner. The police went to his home, where there were minor children. The lawyer will present an appeal, although this does not automatically stop the expulsion order, according to the new immigration law approved last December. The Muslim cleric is accused of instigating jihadist radicalization and also of polygamy The procedure to send the imam to Tunisia, his country of origin, is complex. The consular safe conduct of the Maghreb State is required. Mahjoubi has a residence permit valid until 2029. It seemed that the fact that he was married to a French woman protected him, but the authorities have discovered that the cleric contracted a religious marriage with a Tunisian woman without having yet divorced his French wife. That, according to the law, would be polygamy, an added reason for expulsion. Also read Eusebio Val #imam #called #flag #satanic #arrested #expelled #France

author: Bob Brookover | RBrookover@njadvancemedia.com
title: Eagles offensive linemen drive away with some cool gifts from Jalen Hurts and Saquon Barkley - lehighvalleylive.com
text:
PHILADELPHIA ‚Äî It was a great Christmas to be one of the Eagles‚Äô offensive linemen and it didn‚Äôt matter if you were a starter or a reserve.
Every member of the Eagles‚Äô offensive line showed up at work Tuesday and received a shiny new souped-up gold cart, courtesy of quarterback Jalen Hurts and running back Saquon Barkley.
BUY EAGLES TICKETS: STUBHUB , VIVID SEATS , TICKETMASTER
The team released a video on X Thursday afternoon of the linemen running out of the locker room and toward the golf carts, which were lined up in a row outside of the team‚Äôs NovaCare Complex practice facility. Each cart was customized with the name and numbers of each lineman.
The video shows second-year offensive lineman Tyler Steen driving through the parking lot as 12-year veteran runs toward his gift from Hurts and Barkley, who happily watch the excitement on the faces of their teammates as they approach their Christmas gifts.
Center Cam Jurgens can be seen hugging both Hurts and Barkley before heading for his new ride.
‚Äú Awesome,‚Äù Jurgens said when asked about the gift after practice Thursday. ‚ÄúThat thing is fully loaded: stereo system, backup camera. That thing‚Äôs badass.‚Äù
Jurgens, when asked how he would use it, said, ‚ÄúI might drive it to work.‚Äù
‚ÄùYou know, I haven‚Äôt really decided, but it‚Äôd be pretty nice just driving around here in the summer or maybe take it down to the shore,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know. It might just travel with me everywhere I go.‚Äù
Thank you for relying on us to provide the journalism you can trust. Please consider supporting us with a subscription.
Bob Brookover can be reached at rbrookover@njadvancemedia.com
If you purchase a product or register for an account through a link on our site, we may receive compensation. By using this site, you consent to our User Agreement and agree that your clicks, interactions, and personal information may be collected, recorded, and/or stored by us and social media and other third-party partners in accordance with our Privacy Policy.

author: Grace Tillyard and Bob Norman/Florida Center for Government Accountability
title: Anti-abortion 'infodemic'? Florida's tax-funded Christian pregnancy centers increase targeting women - WGCU
text:
Anti-abortion 'infodemic‚Äô? Florida‚Äôs tax-funded Christian pregnancy centers increase targeting women
When Abby learned she was pregnant, the first thing she did was look online for support. As a college student in a small town in northwest Florida, she thought the Internet was her best hope to find help for her unplanned pregnancy with a boyfriend who had become abusive.
Sifting through Google‚Äôs search results, she stumbled on an online-chat providing support for people in need of abortion care. The chat operator stressed the importance of a pregnancy test and referred her to a nearby pregnancy center in Deland called the Grace House.
The center‚Äôs website welcomed people like Abby who didn‚Äôt have insurance and asked to remain anonymous due to safety concerns. She scheduled a visit for the following day ‚Äì a day she said she‚Äôll never forget.
The horrific visit ended with Abby sobbing as center employees systematically pressured her to continue her pregnancy, prayed over her belly, and promised her free baby care products if she would come back for more ‚Äúcounseling.‚Äù
‚ÄúI deserved legitimate medical care and compassion,‚Äù said Abby. ‚ÄúBut I know in that room, they didn‚Äôt see me or my future. They just saw a positive pregnancy test.‚Äù
The staffers at Grace House were not there to help her receive abortion care, but instead to convince her and all others who enter the center for care to complete their pregnancy and be saved by Christianity in the process.
‚ÄúI was fooled by this facility in a moment of vulnerability and desperation and trusting the wrong people,‚Äù Abby said.
The same ‚Äúwrong people‚Äù are funded by the state‚Äôs Florida Pregnancy Support Services Program, which provides taxpayers‚Äô money to more than 100 anti-abortion ‚Äúcrisis pregnancy centers (CPCs)‚Äù around the state. The stated goal of the program is to convince clients to carry their pregnancies to term rather than having abortions.
As previously reported in an ongoing Florida Trident investigative series, the centers, including Grace House, are Christian-based organizations and often identify themselves as ‚Äúministries‚Äù and ‚Äúmissions.‚Äù Several legal experts have said the program runs afoul of the U.S. and Florida constitutions, the latter of which expressly forbids the state from aiding religious organizations.
Despite its inherent problems, the program is now bursting at the seams in Florida. Its annual budget has ballooned from $4 million to $25 million a year, an increase written into the controversial six-week abortion ban legislation signed by Gov. Ron DeSantis in April.
Included in that funding explosion is a quadrupling of the program‚Äôs advertising budget to nearly $1 million a year, according to state records, paid out via the Florida Pregnancy Care Network, the non-profit tasked with administering the program for the state.
Kurt Filla, owner of the Michigan-based company, Filla Life Media, snared the state-funded advertising contract. Filla, who didn‚Äôt respond to requests for comment, is an outspoken conspiracy theorist who has backed false QAnon and vaccine tropes on the Internet and has written that the 2020 election was stolen, that God sends him angels and he‚Äôs heard the devil talk in his head, and that ‚Äúglobal elites‚Äù are secretly trying to make people ‚Äúimpotent and immobile.‚Äù
Jenifer McKenna, an activist with the Reproductive Health Accountability Fund at Hopewell, said the steep funding hike and hiring of ideologically radical companies like Filla Life are part of a trend in ‚Äúabortion-hostile‚Äù states like Florida to divert tax dollars to CPCs and ‚Äúramp up targeted digital marketing to track down pregnant people, talk them out of abortion, and collect their sensitive data.‚Äù
‚ÄúResearchers are calling the post-Roe landscape an ‚Äòabortion infodemic‚Äô with CPCs playing a leading role,‚Äù said McKenna, adding that the centers use ‚Äúextensive digital strategies to intercept pregnant people seeking care, sow confusion, spread disinformation and obstruct access.‚Äù
After an initial visit, which at some clinics includes an ultrasound where individual center staffers pray for the fetus, clients are urged to return for ‚Äúcounseling‚Äù and parenting classes. In fact, while the state bills the centers as health care providers, a whopping 87.5% of program reimbursements go for counseling and classes, a Trident analysis of state records found. A significant portion of the new $20 million in annual spending will fund a doubling of the amount the state reimburses the centers for counseling from $75 an hour to $150 an hour, state records show.
To put the $150 hourly rate in perspective, the state reimburses registered nurses ‚Äì who actually have formalized education and training for the critical work they do ‚Äì only $32.07 per home health care visit, according to the Florida Agency for Health Care Administration. Home health aides, who lack the RN‚Äôs credentials, are reimbursed a scant $18.04 per visit by the state.
When told of that increase, Amy Weintraub, who serves as reproductive rights director for the non-profit Progress Florida, called it ‚Äúatrocious.‚Äù She noted that the ‚Äúcounselors‚Äù at the centers have no training or education requirements and are often hired based largely on their Christian faith.
‚ÄúThe fact that [state-funded pregnancy centers] are even allowed to use the word ‚Äòcounselor‚Äô is such an affront because ‚Ä¶ they are not trained counselors,‚Äù said Weintraub.
That‚Äôs something Abby said she found out the hard way.
‚ÄúOh, She‚Äôs Abortion-Minded‚Äù
A random online search for abortion in Fort Lauderdale turns up a website for the Hope Women‚Äôs Centers, which received $100,000 in state funding last year. Its website promises ‚Äúfree abortion information‚Äù and ‚Äúconsultations on abortion pills, surgical abortion procedures, and emergency contraceptives.‚Äù
Yet like all other state-funded pregnancy crisis centers, Hope, which is strongly aligned with the Rio Vista Church, has two goals: to dissuade clients from having an abortion and to try to save their souls. None of that is mentioned in the online material.
It was the same in Abby‚Äôs case when she went to Grace House, which recently changed its name to Coastal Choices Women‚Äôs Clinic, a moniker that belies the fact that it vehemently opposes choice and isn‚Äôt a bona fide health clinic. The Trident left a detailed message for comment with a receptionist at Coastal; a promised return call was not received prior to publication.
‚ÄúThere is no Planned Parenthood in my county, so I thought it a smaller version of it,‚Äù said Abby. ‚ÄúAnd they said if you were considering abortion to come on in, so I felt that was an invitation.‚Äù
Once inside, she was given a form to fill out with questions about her faith, her intimate relationships, even what her college grades looked like. It was the first clue she was inside a Christian ministry instead of a bona fide health clinic.
‚ÄúThat gave me a little bit of a pause,‚Äù Abby said. ‚ÄúBut it wasn‚Äôt until the actual counseling session that I deeply regretted walking in the doors.‚Äù
She‚Äôd written in the form that she wanted an abortion.
‚ÄúI watched a group of maybe three staff or volunteers crowd around my paper,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúAnd I hear them say something to the effect of, ‚ÄòOh, she‚Äôs abortion-minded, I‚Äôll take her.‚Äô‚Äù
In the counseling session that followed, which she attended with her partner, Abby took a pregnancy test that was kept hidden while staff pressed her for 40 minutes about her personal life. She said the staffers told her she was in no position to make the decision about an abortion for herself.
When her partner was out of the room, Abby confided that she was in an abusive relationship. She said the counselor advised her to stay with her partner because the baby would give her purpose and help him step up as a man, and urged him, when Abby was outside the room, to stop her from getting an abortion because the procedure could kill her.
After the test came back positive, Abby was handed her due date and a small replica of a fetus. A staffer asked her what she might name the baby. Distraught, Abby began sobbing.
‚ÄúThere was so much talking over me when I was clearly having a breakdown,‚Äù Abby recalled. ‚Äú[One staffer] starts praying over my stomach, she‚Äôs touching my stomach the whole time, and saying that I can start right away taking their parenting classes to earn baby bucks for their boutique to get baby clothes. And all the while I‚Äôm just so terrified.‚Äù
The experience was a far cry from the online promises, a contrast Weintraub said is common. The most fundamental deception in the advertising is the centers‚Äô posing as health clinics when they don‚Äôt actually offer comprehensive reproductive health care services, she said.
‚ÄúThey strip their web sites of anti-abortion lingo so that the intended victims will not realize that the place they are visiting is an anti-abortion center,‚Äù said Weintraub. ‚ÄúAll kinds of tricky language is used to cloak their true intention.‚Äù
Now Filla Life Media, under the leadership of its extremist owner, is set to receive $1 million a year from Florida taxpayers for its marketing prowess.
Tax-Payer Funded Anti-Abortion Marketing Agencies
Filla Life Media is a member of a national network called the Pro-Life Marketing Ethics Council made up of ‚Äúunified Christ-centered and holistically pro-life‚Äù companies dedicated to promoting marketing strategies ‚Äúgrounded in biblical principles and informed by cutting-edge best practices.‚Äù
A key strategy of the Florida program is to boost its anti-abortion clinics in Google search results and place ads on social media platforms like Facebook, Instagram and Tiktok.
‚ÄúIf I‚Äôm in my hometown and I search ‚Äòabortion near me‚Äô it‚Äôs usually the first thing that comes up,‚Äù said Abby.
State documents show the aim of the campaign is to ‚Äúgenerate leads and inquiries‚Äù from pregnant people and that it uses ‚Äúmarketing strategies ‚Ä¶ with the goal of enabling her to carry the pregnancy to term and choose parenting or adoption.‚Äù
The new Filla Life marketing campaign is set to be the most aggressive to date, targeting women aged between 18 and 44 years old across Florida. Many of the ads specifically target teens and the uninsured.
The campaign will employ the latest in tracking technology and will leverage behavioral data‚Äîlike what people are or are not doing in an app, on a website, or how they interact with campaigns‚Äîto personalize the message.
FPCN ads that appear at the top of Google searches for ‚Äúunplanned pregnancy‚Äù or ‚Äúpregnancy test‚Äù promise ‚ÄúCompassionate Counseling,‚Äù ‚ÄúJudgement-Free Pregnancy Support‚Äù and ‚ÄùPregnancy Pill Help.‚Äù Of
134 Google ads purchased this year by marketing companies on behalf of the state program reviewed by the Trident, only three explicitly warned the centers don‚Äôt provide abortions.
While the new ad campaign is super-charged, it‚Äôs nothing new. For years, Floridians‚Äô tax dollars have gone to anti-abortion marketing agencies with little to no transparency. Before Filla Life, an Illinois-based company called Caledon, and its subdivision Choose Life Marketing, held the advertising contract.
The digital tactics promoted by Choose Life, alongside other anti-abortion marketing agencies, sparked
a congressional investigation in 2022 that cited a number of the company‚Äôs tactics, including geofencing strategies, which use sensitive data from abortion seekers to facilitate government surveillance, harassment, intimidation and even violence. The company also featured prominently in a report issued by the Center for Countering Digital Hate, which exposed the deceptive tactics of several anti-abortion marketing agencies.
Those marketing strategies also involved so-called ‚Äúright-brain research‚Äù peddled by the Vitae Foundation, an anti-abortion research organization. Vitae uses extensive interviews with previously pregnant people involving repetition and relaxation techniques to ‚Äúaccess the emotional mind and uncover deeply seated emotional needs and barriers,‚Äù according to its promotional materials.
‚ÄúBy studying the right side of the brain, which controls the emotional, intuitive and creative aspects of the person, Vitae was able to focus on women‚Äôs hidden, emotional response to pregnancy, abortion and motherhood,‚Äù the foundation explained in a report.
A key finding of the foundation is that ‚Äúwomen carry an unwanted pregnancy to term when guilt wins out over shame,‚Äù a concept used by pro-life marketing agencies to craft their messaging to ‚Äúabortion-minded women.‚Äù
Marketing and Counseling: Two Sides of the Same Coin
The state‚Äôs CPC program is driven by more than just religious ideology and anti-abortion zeal ‚Äì there is also the bottom line.
To keep clients coming back for more taxpayer-financed $150-an-hour counseling, the centers often offer ‚Äúbaby bucks‚Äù that Abby mentioned, which is essentially credit for infant care products like diapers and clothes, for every hour they spend with staff in counseling and parenting classes.
Because the Florida Constitution prohibits using state money to fund religious organizations, the program advises individual centers to obtain consent from clients before engaging in religious counseling. Counseling sessions that are religious in nature are also not supposed to be billed to the state, according to the program‚Äôs contract compliance manual.
Adherence to those rules is based on an honor system, termed ‚Äúself-monitoring‚Äù in the FPCN contract. A glaring example of failure in that weak standard is the case of Mary‚Äôs Pregnancy Resource Center (MPRC), which the Trident first reported in June had abruptly shut down its Hollywood location amid six-figure tax liens and an IRS investigation. Employees weren‚Äôt paid and complained to the Trident that the couple that owned the center, Yohanka and Pete Reyes, were spending more time with their prized Saint Bernard show dogs than at the center.
MPRC received about a half-million dollars a year from the state even after its state registration as a non-profit was revoked. FPCN, it was learned, doesn‚Äôt have a mechanism to check if the centers retain their legally-required registration.
Rita Gagliano, FPCN‚Äôs executive director, responded to the Trident‚Äôs questions about MPRC in a written statement back in August, calling Mary‚Äôs an ‚Äúisolated incident that the Florida Pregnancy Care Network is closely looking into and scrutinizing.‚Äù
‚ÄúThese organizations are completely independent of FPCN, and we only provide oversight regarding services that are billable to the program,‚Äù she continued. ‚ÄúWe do not believe the allegations made involving this one center are representative of the program, how it runs or how it will continue to run.‚Äù
The Trident-exposed MPRC debacle could help drive change at the state level. Senate Minority Leader Lauren Book (D-Davie) sponsored a bill in October (SB 256) to mandate the Department of Health to make at least one annual unannounced visit to each state-funded center each year, as well as to impose fines on any center that issues faulty medical information. Earlier this month, Book reiterated the need for passage of her bill in a follow-up article about MPRC
published in the Miami Herald.
‚ÄúFlorida‚Äôs so-called ‚Äòcrisis pregnancy centers‚Äô need accountability and oversight ‚Äî that is obvious and clear,‚Äù said Book in a written statement to the Trident. ‚ÄúThey masquerade as healthcare clinics ‚Äî pushing an anti-choice, anti-health agenda that the State of Florida absurdly continues to fund with taxpayer money.‚Äù
Progress Florida‚Äôs Weintraub said that because FPCN largely relies on the centers to ‚Äúself-monitor‚Äù themselves, more regulation is badly needed.
‚ÄúThere is no way the state or we as advocates can really know what happens [in the counseling sessions] unless the victim reaches out to us,‚Äù said Weintraub. ‚ÄúThat makes it frustrating, and the state has made no effort in training them on separation of church and state issues.‚Äù
While the brunt of the state program funds are spent on counseling, little more than 10 percent is left over for health care services, which are usually limited to pregnancy tests and ultrasounds. For Weintraub the money trail tells the story.
‚ÄúIt shows that they‚Äôre literally all talk,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúThey are not interested in providing health services. All they want to do is shame and pray and create emotional drama and chaos for someone who might be abortion-seeking. It‚Äôs a heinous use of taxpayers‚Äô money.‚Äù
About the Author: Grace Tillyard is an academic researcher and writer who specializes in reproductive politics and data-driven technologies.
About the Author: Bob Norman is an award-winning investigative reporter who serves as Editor-in-Chief of The Florida Trident and journalism program director for the Florida Center for Government Accountability. He can be reached via email at journalism@flcga.org.

author: @ladepechedumidi
title: ENTRETIEN. D√©serts m√©dicaux : "Personne ne croit que les consultations volontaires vont changer quelque chose" - ladepeche.fr
text:
ENTRETIEN. D√©serts m√©dicaux : "Personne ne croit que les consultations volontaires vont changer quelque chose"
Pour l‚Äôancien ministre de la Sant√©, Fr√©d√©ric Valletoux (Horizons), proche d‚Äô√âdouard Philippe, demander √† des m√©decins d‚Äôaller volontairement consulter dans des d√©serts m√©dicaux ne sert √† rien. Pour lui, il faut appliquer d‚Äôautres mesures qui, bien que vot√©es, tardent √† se mettre en place.
Le ministre de la Sant√©, Yannick Neuder, a annonc√© l‚Äôidentification de 151 "zones rouges" touch√©es par les d√©serts m√©dicaux, repr√©sentant deux millions de patients. D√®s septembre 2025, ces territoires recevront la visite de m√©decins g√©n√©ralistes jusqu‚Äô√† deux jours par mois pour des missions dites "de solidarit√© obligatoire". Elles reposeront d‚Äôabord sur le volontariat, avec une compensation financi√®re. Qu‚Äôen pense l‚Äôancien ministre de la Sant√© du gouvernement Attal, Fr√©d√©ric Valletoux, aujourd‚Äôhui d√©put√© de Seine-et-Marne et pr√©sident de la commission des Affaires sociales de l‚ÄôAssembl√©e nationale ?
√Ä lire aussi :
D√©serts m√©dicaux : Tarn, Gers‚Ä¶ quelles sont les 151 zones rouges s√©lectionn√©es pour "la mission de solidarit√© obligatoire" des m√©decins ?
Que pensez-vous de cette carte de 151 zones consid√©r√©es comme √©tant des d√©serts m√©dicaux vers lesquelles vont √™tre envoy√©s les m√©decins ?
Fr√©d√©ric Valletoux : Fonder la politique de lutte contre les d√©serts m√©dicaux sur l‚Äôid√©e que l‚Äôon va demander √† certains m√©decins s‚Äôils acceptent, dans certaines situations, de consacrer quelques heures par semaine √† des consultations dans des zones blanches pas trop loin de chez eux me semble √™tre une fa√ßon tr√®s cosm√©tique de regarder le probl√®me des d√©serts m√©dicaux. Comme cela vient s‚Äôajouter √† d‚Äôautres mesures, peut-√™tre que l‚Äôaccumulation de d√©cisions va permettre que les choses aillent mieux, mais personne ne croit vraiment que cette affaire de consultations volontaires va changer quelque chose, d‚Äôautant que les organisations syndicales sont bien peu allantes sur le sujet.
√Ä lire aussi :
D√©serts m√©dicaux : qu‚Äôest-ce que le "numerus apertus" que le gouvernement veut supprimer pour lutter contre la p√©nurie de m√©decins
Qu‚Äôest-ce qui pourrait vraiment changer les choses ?
Ce qu‚Äôil faudrait, c‚Äôest d√©j√† mettre en ≈ìuvre les mesures qui attendent toujours, comme l‚Äôobligation pour les cliniques priv√©es de participer √† la permanence des soins pour soulager les h√¥pitaux. √áa a √©t√© vot√© en d√©cembre 2023, mais les d√©crets d‚Äôapplication n‚Äôont toujours pas √©t√© pris. Je pense aussi au d√©ploiement sur le territoire des 3 700 m√©decins g√©n√©ralistes de quatri√®me ann√©e d‚Äôinternat, des docteurs juniors, que l‚Äôon va r√©partir sur le territoire. Cela repr√©sente en moyenne une quarantaine de docteurs juniors par d√©partement, qui seront habilement r√©partis. C‚Äôest une mesure qui aura un vrai impact, car un docteur junior, c‚Äôest quelqu‚Äôun qui consulte et prescrit en autonomie, donc qui double la capacit√© d‚Äôun cabinet classique. Cela va fonctionner, car les docteurs juniors n‚Äôauront pas le choix : ils seront affect√©s dans certains endroits et devront y aller. On tourne toujours autour du m√™me pot. On esp√®re que les m√©decins iront volontairement dans des zones non pourvues, alors qu‚Äôeux-m√™mes, dans leurs cabinets, sont d√©bord√©s. C‚Äôest une douce illusion.
√Ä lire aussi :
D√©serts m√©dicaux : un ex-m√©decin radi√© fait le forcing pour reprendre du service et d√©nonce une 'obstruction administrative'
Le 18 juin dernier, une proposition de loi a √©t√© vot√©e au S√©nat, qui exige de prendre en compte les besoins des territoires pour fixer le nombre d‚Äô√©tudiants. C‚Äôest une bonne chose ?
Tout √† fait, cela signifie que nous pouvons nous adapter aux besoins. Mais je le r√©p√®te, des mesures sont d√©j√† pr√™tes √† √™tre mises en ≈ìuvre. Je donne un autre exemple : les infirmiers en pratique avanc√©e. Ce ne sont pas des sous-m√©decins, et ils ne doivent pas l‚Äô√™tre. Ce sont des professionnels qui, √† mi-chemin entre les infirmiers dipl√¥m√©s apr√®s trois ann√©es d‚Äô√©tudes et les m√©decins form√©s en dix √† quinze ans, peuvent exercer apr√®s un cursus de cinq ans. Ils et elles auraient la possibilit√© de prescrire afin de suivre les pathologies chroniques de certains patients, qui n‚Äôont pas toujours besoin d‚Äôaller voir leur m√©decin pour v√©rifier leurs indicateurs de sant√©. Malheureusement, les textes cr√©ant ce statut ne sont toujours pas appliqu√©s, car il y a peu d‚Äôentrain de la part de l‚Äôadministration.
On sait qu‚Äôun ministre doit suivre ses dossiers s‚Äôil ne veut pas qu‚Äôils soient enterr√©s. L‚Äôinstabilit√© politique, qui a engendr√© un important turnover au minist√®re de la Sant√©, ralentit-elle l‚Äôapplication des mesures vot√©es ?
C‚Äôest √©vident. J‚Äôai √©t√© le septi√®me ministre de la Sant√© en sept ans, Yannick Neuder le neuvi√®me en sept ans‚Ä¶ Dans ce contexte, c‚Äôest l‚Äôadministration qui gouverne. Quand j‚Äô√©tais rue de S√©gur (NDLR : le si√®ge du minist√®re de la Sant√©), l‚Äôadministration me regardait comme un ministre de passage, et l‚Äôhistoire lui a donn√© raison. Cette rotation tr√®s importante renvoie l‚Äôid√©e que la sant√© est accessoire, mais surtout, elle ne peut que d√©boucher sur une forme d‚Äôimmobilisme.

author: Middle East Media Research Institute
title: Mohamed Hassaballa in NJ Friday Sermon: Christians Are Open Idolaters; Being Humble Does Not...
text: In his Friday sermon on December 6, 2024, at the Clifton location of the Islamic Center of Passaic County, Mohamed Hassaballah stated that ‚Äúthe Christians are open idolaters.‚Äù He further explained that being humble can sometimes be misconstrued as being ‚Äúsubdued.‚Äù However, he emphasized that there is no conflict between ‚Äúlowering your wings‚Äù to Muslims while also demonstrating strength and overtaking the disbelievers. He asserted that they fight and wage Jihad on the path of Allah, undeterred by headlines, public opinion, or any plots against them.

author: Albane Harmange
title: M√©t√©o d'automne et manque de soleil, un d√©ficit record en Lorraine
text:
Selon les derniers chiffres de M√©t√©o France Grand Est, l'automne 2024 √©tait tr√®s peu ensoleill√©. Les pr√©visionnistes ont comptabilis√© 271 heures et 31 minutes d'ensoleillement √† Nancy (Meurthe-et-Moselle) pour les mois de septembre, octobre et d√©cembre. Un d√©ficit record depuis 2001.
C√¥t√© m√©t√©o, ce vendredi 13 d√©cembre pourrait √™tre synonyme de chance. Malgr√© le froid, le soleil a point√© le bout de son nez. Et cela faisait un moment qu'il √©tait rest√© cach√©. Durant cet automne, le soleil √©tait timide, tellement timide que le d√©ficit d'ensoleillement a battu des records. Selon les chiffres de M√©t√©o France Grand Est, la Lorraine a m√™me v√©cu son automne le moins ensoleill√© du XXI·µâ si√®cle.
Un d√©ficit de 20 %
Pour les mois de septembre, octobre et novembre, les climatologues ont relev√© un total de 271 heures et 31 minutes d'ensoleillement sur la station de Nancy-Essey. Alors que le taux normal est de 328 heures et 36 minutes. √Ä √âpinal, un d√©ficit de 20 % est aussi constat√© avec 282 heures ensoleill√©es sur les trois derniers mois, contre 347 heures dans une situation optimale.
Comme le souligne Roland Alberti, pr√©visionniste climatologue √† M√©t√©o France Grand Est, les mois de septembre, octobre et novembre ont tous √©t√© d√©ficitaires. Il explique ce manque de source de vitamine D par un temps tr√®s perturb√© pour le mois de septembre, donc avec beaucoup de nuages. Un ph√©nom√®ne qui s'est r√©p√©t√© en octobre, suivi par une situation anti-cyclonique qui a cr√©√© des conditions propices pour des nuages bas et du brouillard. "L'insolation (ensoleillement) √©tait meilleure dans les montagnes vosgiennes, au-dessus des nuages", ajoute Roland Alberti. En novembre, le brouillard toujours pr√©sent a emp√™ch√© les habitants de Lorraine d'apercevoir le soleil.
‚òÅÔ∏èDepuis le d√©but du mois, avec des brouillards et nuages bas, le soleil a √©t√© tr√®s souvent absent sur la moiti√© nord du pays. Il n‚Äôy a g√©n√©ralement pas eu une seule ¬´ journ√©e ensoleill√©e ¬ª.
‚Äî M√©t√©o-France (@meteofrance)
üå•Ô∏èOn peut citer Rennes avec seulement 25 min de soleil.
üëâ[https://t.co/9HXVF3WVKo][pic.twitter.com/GCWymtyP7k][November 14, 2024]
Le record du si√®cle
Toutes ces conditions cumul√©es font que l'automne 2024 figure parmi les 10 automnes les moins ensoleill√©s depuis 1970. C'est l'ann√©e 1974 qui d√©tient le record avec 190 heures d'ensoleillement seulement pendant trois mois. Mais au XXI·µâ si√®cle, l'automne 2024 d√©croche la palme du d√©ficit de soleil. Si vous avez eu un coup de blues durant cette saison, vous avez peut-√™tre une explication. Le soleil agit sur la production de deux hormones : la s√©rotonine ou "hormone du bonheur", et la m√©latonine qui r√®gle le cycle du sommeil.
Le soleil est aussi la principale source de vitamine D, et le manque de cette hormone peut engendrer des risques de faiblesse musculaire, un syst√®me immunitaire plus faible ou des probl√®mes osseux. En cas de blues hivernal ou de d√©pression saisonni√®re hivernale, n'h√©sitez pas √† consulter un professionnel de sant√© afin qu'il vous prescrive un traitement adapt√©. Et esp√©rons que l'hiver soit √† l'image de ce 13 d√©cembre, et batte plut√¥t des records d'ensoleillement.
